newsitem.title: FRANCE: Eurotunnel all-clear to wagons, new safety rules.
newsitem.headline: Eurotunnel all-clear to wagons, new safety rules.

text.p: Eurotunnel SA Plc said on Thursday it had given the all-clear to its freight rolling stock and said it was confident it did not need costly redesign in the aftermath of last November's Channel Tunnel blaze.
But it pledged to spend 21 million stg on other new safety measures.

Publishing the findings of its inquiry into the November 18 fire which swept through a main tunnel causing widespread damage and reduced services, Eurotunnel said it planned to spend most of the money on installing fire stations and water hydrants for the tunnel.
New safety systems will cost 20 million pounds, with one to one-and-a-half million earmarked for increased staffing levels and training.
But the final verdict will not lie with the company but the Channel Tunnel Safety Authority which has yet to report back.
Co-chairman Patrick Ponsolle told a press conference, "We've spent the last few weeks discussing our proposals in depth and these are still going on and will continue in the coming weeks.
Eurotunnel appears confident of clearance, however, predicting a resumption of freight services by mid-June.

Both co-chairmen, Ponsolle and Robert Malpas vigorously denied that they were placing profit before safety by deciding not to redesign the controversial open-sided freight wagons where the fire broke out.
"I have heard the view that we were torn between safety and our finances. Well let me tell you simply -- as chairman of this company I have never experienced this contradiction.
"We can only be successful if our customers are convinced it is one of the safest transport systems in the world," said Ponsolle.
Malpas said its first priority was protecting passengers, with the group assets coming second.
He said the Kent Fire Brigade in England, which fought the 1,000 degree centrigrade fire last year, was wrong to infer that the design of the open wagons fanned the blaze.
The KFB has called on Eurotunnel to close the sides of the freight wagons, saying the latticed frames acted like "blow torch" last time.
"I've read reports of the blow-torch effect. It does not exist. It is a fallacy; nothing could prove its existence," said Malpas, claiming Eurotunnel had expert advice on this.

But the group has made some key changes. First, in the event of a fire in a main tunnel, the train will make a stop near the next available entry point to the safety tunnel -- a separate and sealed tunnel running parallel which has been described as a "permanent lifeboat" in case of disaster.
Previously a train would have continued until it left the tunnel.
Passengers will have access to protective masks if smoke enters the cabins.
More checks will be made on trains before they depart and as they arrive at stations and freight trucks will also be closely monitored before the train leaves the station.
Eurotunnel will boost links with the control centre and the train captain will be responsible for train evacuation.
The Anglo-French tunnel group admitted that even with its new systems in place it would not be 100 percent safe.

Ponsolle told the briefing, "I am not optimistic to say it will never happen again. I do not believe you can provide 100 percent safety." But he said the new procedures would give a speedier reaction if November 18 was ever repeated.
